claim_text: The NeuroReach VR system is a proof-of-concept mixed-reality application designed to enhance selective muscle activation in the arms for stroke rehabilitation. It utilizes an ARAT-aligned pouring task and an MX Ink tracing task, incorporating visual, auditory, and haptic feedback to aid in the rehabilitation process. The system is intended to be intuitive and motivational, leveraging gamified elements for a more engaging user experience. The project aims to improve motor control and functional recovery in stroke survivors through targeted exercises within a virtual environment.
summary: The system's effectiveness and clinical applicability are not yet proven, as it is still in the proof-of-concept stage.
detail: The claim describes the NeuroReach VR system as a 'proof-of-concept' application. While it outlines the intended features, tasks, and feedback mechanisms, the provided evidence focuses on the development plan, technical challenges, and proposed solutions for creating the system. There is no mention of any pilot studies or clinical trials that have been conducted to evaluate the system's actual effectiveness, user outcomes, or its potential for clinical application beyond a proposed demonstration plan. The evidence mentions a 'pilot study and analysis' planned for weeks 9-12, indicating that the system is still in its early stages of evaluation.

engagement and selective activation. Outcome: Quick add-on with extra KPIs (time-in-target, ratio, co-contraction)
and demo toggle mode.

Members Responsible: A. Elsig, R. Fl¨uckiger
Description: Rule based adaptation of corridor, tilt window and tracing tunnel; feedback fading from knowledge of

Members Responsible: P. S. Purkayastha, R. Khoshimov
Description: Evaluate the system with a 5-10 participant pilot study; Test usability and performance using a baseline,
training, retention protocol to inform final refinements. Outcomes: A polished system with documentation; A formal
study protocol with a performance dataset; A completed usability and analysis report. Challenges: Participant
recruitment delays; Technical instability. Solutions: Recruit early; Conduct internal dry runs to fix bugs. Alternatives:

claim_text: The system features an adaptive controller that adjusts task difficulty, such as the corridor, tilt window, and tracing tunnel, based on user performance. Feedback mechanisms are designed to fade from providing knowledge of performance to knowledge of results as the user progresses. A projected dashboard will display real-time metrics like on path, tilt window, spills proxy, RMS error, and SPARC to observe adaptive difficulty and feedback fading. This adaptive approach aims to prevent overreactive difficulty oscillations and metric drift across sessions by using solutions like moving averages.
summary: The claim describes an adaptive controller and feedback fading mechanisms, but the evidence focuses on specific task implementations and technical challenges without detailing these adaptive features.
detail: The claim (c0002) extensively details an adaptive controller that adjusts task difficulty and a feedback mechanism that fades from knowledge of performance to knowledge of results. It also mentions specific solutions like moving averages to prevent oscillations and metric drift. However, the provided evidence snippets (E1 and E2) primarily describe the technical implementation of specific tasks (pouring, tracing), the hardware used (Quest 3S), and the challenges encountered (anchor drift, noisy tilt estimation). While E1 mentions 'UI to configure thresholds,' it does not elaborate on how these thresholds are dynamically adjusted by an adaptive controller based on user performance, nor does it describe the fading feedback mechanism. The evidence does not confirm or deny the existence or functionality of the adaptive controller or the feedback fading as described in the claim.

I. DESCRIPTION OF THE PROJECT
Goal: To build NeuroReach VR – a proof-of-concept mixed-reality system that trains stroke reach and grasp using
an ARAT-aligned pouring task [1] and an MX Ink tracing task with visual, auditory and haptic feedback [6], to
improve selective muscle activation in the arms for stroke rehabilitation. [2].
Idea: Quest 3S with Shared Spatial Anchors pins virtual halos to a real cup and jug while MX Ink provides stylus
pose and pressure for tracing with haptic ticks via Unity SendHapticImpulse. We compute on path, time in tilt
window, spill proxy and smoothness with SPARC, and adapt difficulty to keep the user in a target corridor.
Rationale: The design draws on motor learning and control theory, emphasizing that stroke recovery combines
adaptation and skill learning to achieve specific task goals [5]. Guided by optimal feedback control, path corri-
dors, goal halos, and error-contingent cues support goal-directed corrections. Task-specific ADL movements with
validated kinematic metrics use SPARC for smoothness, while conservative auditory pacing maintains performance
consistency [3].
II. WORK PACKAGES AND TIMELINE
Hardware & Software: The system runs on Meta Quest 3S using Logitech MX Ink for precision input and haptic
feedback, with an optional Myo armband for EMG biofeedback. It is developed in Unity (C#) for Android, logs
data in CSV and JSON formats, and uses Python notebooks for quick analysis and visualization.
Work Package 1 : Data Anchors, Integration and Calibration (Weeks 1–2)
Members Responsible: R. Khoshimov, A. Elsig
Description: Set up Quest 3 passthrough and Spatial Anchors; integrate MX Ink input and haptics; implement
CSV logger. Outcomes: Unity project with anchors and passthrough; MX Ink tracing sample running with haptic
ticks; one tap calibration UI. Challenges: Anchor drift; noisy tilt estimation; inconsistent haptic support. Solutions:
Relocalize anchors at session start; low pass tilt and debounce events;. Alternatives: Use fiducials instead of anchors;
run tracing without haptics.

claim_text: The system's intuitiveness and motivational aspects suggest potential for clinical application in stroke rehabilitation. A live on-headset demonstration will showcase quick anchor calibration, pouring blocks, and tracing blocks with real-time feedback like halos and ticks. A projected dashboard will provide real-time observation of adaptive difficulty and fading feedback based on user muscle activation. An offline video presentation will be used to showcase the full functionality and capabilities of the NeuroReach VR system.
summary: The claim overstates the system's readiness for clinical application by not acknowledging significant technical challenges and limitations.
detail: The claim suggests the system has potential for clinical application in stroke rehabilitation and will showcase its capabilities. However, the evidence highlights several significant challenges that are still being addressed, including anchor drift, noisy tilt estimation, inconsistent haptic support, and potential overreactive difficulty oscillation. These issues directly impact the reliability and accuracy of the system's feedback and adaptive features, which are crucial for clinical use. The evidence also mentions alternatives like running tracing without haptics or using fiducials instead of anchors, indicating that the current implementation may not be robust enough for its intended purpose without further development and validation.
